text:
Would you rather break a bone or sprain a
ligament?

Assuming you’re looking to get back up and
around quickly, you should hope for the broken
bone.

Bones are much more active and better equipped
to rebuild themselves than ligaments are,
helping fractures heal surprisingly quickly.
Welcome to MinuteEarth.

It’s easy to think of bones as lifeless,
but the bones inside us are actually really
lively.

To stay strong, bones keep rebuilding themselves
throughout much of your life.

This process - called “remodelling” - replaces
an un-bone-lieveable 20% of your skeleton
every single year.

On top of that, your bones have other jobs
too; they’re also responsible for making

new blood cells, and storing fat and minerals
for use throughout your body.

All this work requires lots of resources to
provide energy and nutrients which your constantly-flowing

blood carries to nearly every millimeter of
your skeleton.

So when a bone breaks, blood is right there;
it immediately floods the fracture with the
resources the bone needs to rebuild itself.

With that bone-anza of supplies at hand, most
fractures can heal in about six weeks.

On the other hand, the bundles of connective
tissue called “ligaments'' have basically

one job - holding you together - and don’t
remodel over time, so they don’t need many
resources.

Instead of a bone-ified blood supply, ligaments
rely on energy and nutrients that diffuse
secondhand from nearby tissues.

So when a ligament gets damaged - what we
call a “sprain” - the resources it needs

to repair itself arrive in a trickle, rather
than a flood.

That’s why sprains take way longer than
fractures to heal - at least ten weeks.

And certain ligaments - like the ACL in your
knee - are far enough from a blood supply
that they may never heal on their own.

This rule of thumb - a better blood supply
equals faster healing - holds true across

most of your body, from super-slow-healing
cartilage, which has even less access to blood

than ligaments, to muscles, which are basically
full of blood and, as a result, can heal in
days.

Weirdly though, the fastest-healing tissue
in your body - the cornea - has no direct

blood supply; after all, if your corneas,
the windows at the front of your eyes, were
full of blood, it would leave you seeing red.

Instead, the rest of your eye has a great
blood supply, which constantly pumps resources

into the super-nutritious, crystal-clear,
fluid right behind your cornea.

So in the end, healing is really about quick,
easy access to resources - blood is just the

body’s most common way to bone up after
injury.

Make no bones about it: science helps us understand
the world - especially the unintuitive stuff.

And understanding the world is important when
you’re trying to make a difference in it.

That’s why we’re excited to partner with
GiveWell, a data-driven organization that
researches the effectiveness of certain charities.

GiveWell spends tens of thousands of hours
each year digging into various charities to

figure out how effective they are at solving
the problems they claim they want to solve,

and then they make that research public - warts
and all - to help the rest of us decide what
charities to support.

It’s totally free, with no sign up required,
and right now, if you donate for the first

time to one of their top charities, GiveWell
will match your donation dollar-for-dollar
up to $250.
